info.name: Dentate nucleus
info.description: The dentate nucleus is the largest and most lateral of the deep cerebellar nuclei. It appears as a highly-convoluted draw-string purse with a small opening or hilus from which its efferent fibers exit on their way to the superior cerebellar peduncle. Afferents to the dentate nucleus are primarily from the neocerbellar cortex or lateral aspects of the hemispheres. Efferents terminate primarily in the ventral lateral nucleus of thalamus. Because of a similar shape, it can be confused with the inferior olivary nucleus found in the medulla.
